text: However, due to the lack of a fully tractable reverse-genetics (RG) system for RVs until recently, previous studies on NSP5 have been carried out using mutants expressed in the absence of a complete set of viral proteins. Here, we took advantage of the novel plasmid-only-based, helper virus-free RG systems for rotaviruses (28, 29) to gain new insights into the mechanisms of NSP5 hyperphosphorylation and its role in viroplasm assembly and virus replication during viral infection.
